title: Modeling Actuations in BCI-O: A Context-based Integration of SOSA and IoT-O

sentences.text: Recent technological developments in Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) will largely enable BCI as a powerful, natural and intuitive mainstream human-computer interaction (HCI) in real-world activities, especially throughout actuators connected to the Internet.
As a type of sensor-actuator system, BCI will integrate novel interfaces that will be fully interoperating with IoT-based systems.

An ontological metadata overlay for BCI systems in real-world applications is defined in the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which formalizes and integrates BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model for describing any kind of real/virtual environments.
This paper presents the design principle of BCI-O's Actuation Model, which integrates SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms for actuations and actuators along with the BCI-O's Context Model.

This model will become relevant in the degree as context-based semantic interoperability will become a core pre-requisite for any context-aware BCI actuation application with real-time collaboration in IoT environments.

Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) are systems that determine a user's brain states by collecting and analyzing her neurophysiological signals (which are highly situational, individual dependent, and non-stationary in characteristics) and then actuating specific responses, for example to drive her wheelchair autonomously.

Key developments in wearable sensors, wireless networks, and distributed computing will largely enable BCI as a powerful, natural and intuitive mainstream human-computer interaction (HCI) in real-world activities.
In a not too far future, BCI will be regarded as the ultimate HCI system, integrating novel interfaces that will be fully interoperating with Internet-of-Things- (IoT)-based systems.
In this scenario, context-based semantic interoperability will be a core pre-requisite for any context-aware BCI application with real-time collaboration in IoT environments.

The BCI Ontology (BCI-O) [1] is the first OWL 2 ontology that formalizes relevant metadata for BCI data capture activities by integrating BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model for describing any kind of real/virtual environments.

Due that BCI is a type of sensor-actuator system, as an ontological metadata overlay for BCI systems in real-world applications, BCI-O is properly aligned with the W3C Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) and Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) [2] upper ontologies.

Because many BCI devices, especially actuators, are connected to the Internet, BCI-O is also aligned with the core actuation semantic model for the IoT ontology (IoT-O) [3]: the Semantic Actuator Network (SAN) [5].
BCI-O makes an important contribution: the introduction of the concepts of context and contextual relations [1].

This puts the architectural description of any context as a first-class semantic model that enables BCI applications to be context-aware, laying the foundations of meaningful interactions with IoT-based systems.
This paper presents the structure and design principle of BCI-O's Actuation Model, which integrates SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms for actuations and actuators along with the BCI-O's Context Model.
A use case for this model is explained in a subsequent section.
Lastly, the main contribution is summarized in the conclusions.
BCI-O origins, purpose, core models, global overview, public access (spec and examples), design principles, and applications are described in [1].

At its core, BCI-O defines the conceptual components in any BCI through a bidirectional subject-context interaction model (a BCI session with sensors/actuators): a Sense Model (context to subject) and an Actuation Model (subject to context), as depicted in Fig. 1.
Its Actuation Model is based on the
Two distinct conceptual domains are found in this interaction model: BCI domain (observations, actuations, and interactions) and context domain (surroundings).
Following, a brief description of BCI-O's core modules related to actuations are presented:
Session: represents the interaction between a bci:Subject and a bci:Context while performing (bci:Session) a single bci:Activity.
A bci:Session groups both observations (multimodal records: bci:Record) and actuations (bci:Actuation).
Context: captures the architectural description of any physical/virtual environment.
Its conceptual components enable the structural, functional, and temporal complexity definitions of any environment (Fig. 4).

Under the bci:Context.Event classification, BCI-O defines three key concepts that bind the contextual integration (including with its Actuation Model): bci:StimulusEvent (a stimulus to the bci:Subject), bci:Action (issued by a bci:Subject while performing a bci:Activity), and bci:ActuationEvent (an effect -change of state- in bci:Context as the result of bci:Actuation).
Observations: describes the contextual input data and events to the subject [3].
Specific concepts aligned to the SOSA/SSN axioms [2] are defined for modeling observations.

These are related to bci:Record (a single observation, and input to an actuator), bci:Modality types, aspects (bci:Aspect), channeling specs (bci:ChannelingSpec), sensor output (bci:RecordedData), and bci:StimulusEvent.
Actuation: integrated concepts aligned to the SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms for modeling actuations and actuators.
This model depicts how the bci:Subject can interact with the bci:Context [3].
This model was developed based on the following premises:
Aims to integrate and reconcile SOSA and SAN axioms for modeling actuations and actuators (Fig. 2 and Fig. 3).
Follows closely the proposed Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) ontology design pattern [4]: a core model for the IoT Ontology (IoT-O)1 [3] (Fig. 3).
3.1 Core Abstractions
Actuation: Carries out a procedure to change the state of the context using an actuator.
The relationships from and to actuation and other concepts are the ones defined at [2].
bci:Actuation is aligned to both sosa:Actuation and san:Actuation.

Actuation Event: Represents a transition (something that has changed from a state to a different one: actuation target) ─ a modification (impacted property, as a consequence of an actuation effect) ─ in the context as the result of an actuation (actuation result involves actuation event).
From the context perspective, this concept is a context event (triggered by an actuator) that changes the impacted property of the actuation target.
bci:ActuationEvent is aligned to both bci:Context.Event and san:Effect.
Following the AAE ODP [4], this concept is taken from the following relationships involving the san:Effect definition [5]:
san:Actuator - (triggers) -> san:Effect
san:Actuation - (involves) -> san:Effect
san:Effect - (impacts) -> bci:ImpactedProperty
Actuation Result: It represents the result of an actuation [2], i.e. an entity representing the “effect” of the actuation, which involves an actuation event.
bci:ActuationResult is aligned to both sosa:Result and san:ActuationValue.
Following the AAE ODP [4], this concept expands the following relationship:
san:Actuation - (involves) -> san:Effect
Actuation Target: Its modeling depiction is based on the composition of three concepts.
The first, as a sosa:FeatureOfInterest [2]: the thing (actuation target) whose property (impacted property) is being manipulated by an actuator.

The second, related from a sosa:Actuation via the property sosa:hasFeatureOfInterest [2]: a relation between an actuation and the entity (actuation target) whose property (an impacted property as a consequence of an actuation effect) was modified.
And the third one, a bci:Context.Object: a thing (object) in the contextual interaction of the bci:Session.
bci:ActuationTarget is aligned to both bci:Context.Object and sosa:FeatureOfInterest.
Following the AAE ODP [4], this concept captures the definition of sosa:FeatureOfInterest from the following relation:
bci:ImpactedProperty - (is property of) -> sosa:FeatureOfInterest
Actuator: A device that is used by, or implements, an actuation that changes the state of the context.
According to [3], actuators are devices that transform an input signal into a physical output, making them the exact opposite of sensors.
bci:Actuator is aligned to both sosa:Actuator and san:Actuator.
Command: Represents a specific order (based on a bci:Record) to an actuator to perform an actuation.
Typically, it depicts an instruction (or signal) that causes an actuator to perform (executes) one of its basic functions, and thus, triggering an actuation.
A command defines the input for a set of actuators from a specific source: a set of bci:Record.
bci:Command is aligned to both dul:Method and san:ActuatorInput.
Following the AAE ODP [4], this concept is based on the following definition:
[AAE::Actuator] - (AAE::consumes) -> [AAE::Input]
bci:Actuator - (bci:executes) -> bci:Command
Impacted Property: Represents an actuatable quality (property or characteristic) of an actuation target.

An actuator connects to an impacted property (as a consequence of an actuation effect) via the object property ssn:forProperty [2], i.e., an actuator triggers an actuation event that causes an effect (modification) on the actuation target: impacted property [4].
bci:ImpactedProperty is aligned to sosa:ActuatableProperty.
Following the AAE ODP [4], this concept captures the definition of Impacted Property (linked to san:Effect) from the following relationships:
san:Effect - (impacts) -> bci:ImpactedProperty
bci:ImpactedProperty - (is property of) -> sosa:FeatureOfInterest
3.2 Modeling Integration: BCI-O Context Model with SOSA and SAN Alignments
As a broad application domain ontology for BCI activities, BCI-O integrates and refines some modeling considerations of the SOSA and SAN concepts regarding actuations and actuators.
The “context-aware” domain level concepts were aligned initially to SOSA/SSN.
Afterwards, they were integrated with proper alignments to SAN (IoT-O), following closely their axiomatization satisfiability.
The main modeling integration was done with the actuation event alignment to san:Effect (or san:ActuatorOutput).
san:Effect is defined in [5] as “concept bound to the definition of an actuator as an agent having an effect on the physical world.
Therefore, an effect is any kind of physical modification induced by an actuator”.

In order to be more semantically precise, and based on the SOSA/SSN definitions aligned with Dolce-Ultralite (DUL) in [2] (Vertical Segmentation: DUL alignment module), the concept san:Effect is described distinctively by the following combined ontological notions along with BCI-O's Context Model:

A happening that impacts a quality (dul:Quality), or property (ssn:Property), with the capability of an actuation to act on it (sosa:actsOnProperty), that is, a type of sosa:ActuatableProperty, i.e. the bci:ImpactedProperty.
An event (dul:Event) triggered by an actuator, that modifies (changes) the physical world (actuation target): a type of bci:Context.Event; the actuation event.

(An effect is seeing as...) Any kind (of an impacted property) of physical modification (an effect on the physical world — context) as the result of an actuation (an actuation result involves an actuation event), induced by an actuator (a characteristic of its nature, as an agent that has an effect on the context).
An actuation event is a bci:Context.Event triggered by an actuator that changes the state of the actuation target (which is a bci:Context.Object) (see Fig. 4).
Another inherited modeling perspective for BCI, comes from the definition of san:impacts object property: san:Effect - ( san:impacts ) -> oldssn:Property.
Also, BCI-O's alignment to SAN allows the following inferred relationship:
bci:ActuationEvent - (·san:impacts·) -> bci:ImpactedProperty

Last, in order to be consistent in the BCI-O's overall structure and intention, direct alignments to DUL were considered carefully evaluating the scope and constraints for each concept, which led to properly define class hierarchies and disjoint axioms, especially for its Actuation Model.
The following use case depicts how to define related BCI-O actuation concepts (its description and source code is available online in the spec's human-readable version [1]).
Its purpose is to use an actuator capable to control a wheelchair based on the input from a BCI/EEG record (obtained directly from the subject's head).

In this use case, Alice is driving a wheelchair throughout a human interface composed of three major components: (1) an EEG sensor capable of reading brain signals, (2) a computing system capable to process and analyze (classify) the brain signals collected from the EEG sensor, and (3) an actuator capable to control the wheelchair's movement (such as direction and acceleration) based on the input from the EEG recordings.

The actuator is a device that implements the procedure (actuation) to control the wheelchair, which triggers a series of steps aimed to change the wheelchair's state, such as to decelerate its wheels.
The input to the actuator are the observed and processed brain signals that issue specific movement commands.
For example, the “slow down” command with the parameters (and values) of “direction” (“go forward” -no change in the direction-) and “acceleration” (-10.5 cm/s² -change in the speed-).
The modeled concepts involved in this scenario (see Fig.5), excluding those from the observation component (except EEG-Record and EEG-Device), are listed below:
bci:Subject (1 individual = x1): “Alice”.
bci:Session (x1): “a situation where the EEG recording and actuation happened”.
bci:Activity (x1): “controlling the automated wheelchair”.
bci:Context (x1): “at home”.
bci:Context.Scene (x1): “specific indoors situation”.
bci:EegRecord (x1): “EEG observation that serves as the input of the actuations”.
bci:EegDevice (x1): “EEG device that made the EEG recordings”.
bci:Command (x1): “slow down”, actuators' input from the EEG record.
bci:Actuator (2 individuals = x2): “the devices that perform the actuations”.
bci:Actuation (x2): “procedures that change the state of the wheels via actuators”.
bci:ImpactedProperty (x2): “the speed of the wheels (their state)”.
bci:ActuationEvent (x2): “reduce the speed of wheels”.
bci:ActuationResult (x2): “slowing down” (“effect of decelerating the wheels”).
bci:ActuationTarget (x2): “two rear wheels”.
bci:Context.Object (composite) (x1): “wheelchair”.
bci:Context.Method (x1): “deceleration of a wheel”.

BCI-O's Actuation Model provides a mechanism to correlate the observed/analyzed raw data [1], with the contextual components that the subject interacts with, through actuators (IoT devices), identifying how the actuations affect the context.
This is useful in BCI context-aware applications to model how subjects use actuators and interact with the environment, for “intelligent” subject-context personalization.
BCI-O's Actuation Model integrates carefully both standard axiomatization models for actuations, developed by W3C/OGC [2] and IoT [3] [5] communities, based on its Context Model.
Thus, its structure follows closely the AAE ODP [4], while aligning to SOSA/SSN and SAN (IoT-O) concepts, based on contextual notions.

The SOSA-SAN integrated Actuation Model of BCI-O represents a major contribution to the IoT and BCI communities, especially because its structure includes contextual notions that enables its usage in context-aware BCI-IoT integrated applications.
Semantically-enabled BCIs will play a key role in the future “Internet of Brains” interoperating completely with IoT [6].

Under this vision, where one could semantically model, interoperate and control real life objects throughout BCIs connected to the Internet, BCI-O's Actuation Model would become a core semantic structure that integrates BCI, IoT, and contextual concepts in real-world scenarios.

It is important noting that as part of the BCI-O's Actuation Model development, the author raised the issue to the W3C Spatial Data on the Web Working Group [7], regarding the mapping of SOSA/SSN to AAE ODP, due of their structural resemblance.

summary:
Recent technological developments in Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) will largely enable BCI as a powerful, natural and intuitive mainstream human-computer interaction (HCI) in real-world activities, especially throughout actuators connected to the Internet. As a type of sensor-actuator system, BCI will integrate novel interfaces that will be fully interoperating with IoT-based systems. An ontological metadata overlay for BCI systems in real-world applications is defined in the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which formalizes and integrates BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model for describing any kind of real/virtual environments. This paper presents the design principle of BCI-O's Actuation Model, which integrates SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms for actuations and actuators along with the BCI-O's Context Model. This model will become relevant in the degree as context-based semantic interoperability will become a core pre-requisite for any context-aware BCI actuation application with real-time collaboration in IoT environments.

Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) are systems that determine a user's brain states by collecting and analyzing her neurophysiological signals (which are highly situational, individual dependent, and non-stationary in characteristics) and then actuating specific responses, for example to drive her wheelchair autonomously. Key developments in wearable sensors, wireless networks, and distributed computing will largely enable BCI as a powerful, natural and intuitive mainstream human-computer interaction (HCI) in real-world activities. In a not too far future, BCI will be regarded as the ultimate HCI system, integrating novel interfaces that will be fully interoperating with Internet-of-Things- (IoT)-based systems. In this scenario, context-based semantic interoperability will be a core pre-requisite for any context-aware BCI application with real-time collaboration in IoT environments. The BCI Ontology (BCI-O) [1] is the first OWL 2 ontology that formalizes relevant metadata for BCI data capture activities by integrating BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model for describing any kind of real/virtual environments. Due that BCI is a type of sensor-actuator system, as an ontological metadata overlay for BCI systems in real-world applications, BCI-O is properly aligned with the W3C Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) and Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) [2] upper ontologies. Because many BCI devices, especially actuators, are connected to the Internet, BCI-O is also aligned with the core actuation semantic model for the IoT ontology (IoT-O) [3]: the Semantic Actuator Network (SAN) [5]. BCI-O makes an important contribution: the introduction of the concepts of context and contextual relations [1]. This puts the architectural description of any context as a first-class semantic model that enables BCI applications to be context-aware, laying the foundations of meaningful interactions with IoT-based systems. This paper presents the structure and design principle of BCI-O's Actuation Model, which integrates SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms for actuations and actuators along with the BCI-O's Context Model. A use case for this model is explained in a subsequent section. Lastly, the main contribution is summarized in the conclusions.

BCI-O origins, purpose, core models, global overview, public access (spec and examples), design principles, and applications are described in [1]. At its core, BCI-O defines the conceptual components in any BCI through a bidirectional subject-context interaction model (a BCI session with sensors/actuators): a Sense Model (context to subject) and an Actuation Model (subject to context), as depicted in Fig. 1. Its Actuation Model is based on the

Two distinct conceptual domains are found in this interaction model: BCI domain (observations, actuations, and interactions) and context domain (surroundings). Following, a brief description of BCI-O's core modules related to actuations are presented:

Session: represents the interaction between a bci:Subject and a bci:Context while performing (bci:Session) a single bci:Activity. A bci:Session groups both observations (multimodal records: bci:Record) and actuations (bci:Actuation).

Context: captures the architectural description of any physical/virtual environment. Its conceptual components enable the structural, functional, and temporal complexity definitions of any environment (Fig. 4). Under the bci:Context.Event classification, BCI-O defines three key concepts that bind the contextual integration (including with its Actuation Model): bci:StimulusEvent (a stimulus to the bci:Subject), bci:Action (issued by a bci:Subject while performing a bci:Activity), and bci:ActuationEvent (an effect -change of state- in bci:Context as the result of bci:Actuation).

Observations: describes the contextual input data and events to the subject [3]. Specific concepts aligned to the SOSA/SSN axioms [2] are defined for modeling observations. These are related to bci:Record (a single observation, and input to an actuator), bci:Modality types, aspects (bci:Aspect), channeling specs (bci:ChannelingSpec), sensor output (bci:RecordedData), and bci:StimulusEvent.

Actuation: integrated concepts aligned to the SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms for modeling actuations and actuators. This model depicts how the bci:Subject can interact with the bci:Context [3].

The BCI-O (Brain-Computer Interface Ontology) integrates SOSA and SAN axioms to model actuations and actuators. It follows the Actuation-Actuator-Effect ontology design pattern, aligning with IoT-ontology. The main concepts include: Actuation, which carries out a procedure using an actuator; Actuation Event, representing a transition in context as a result of an actuation; Actuation Result, representing the effect of an actuation; and Impacted Property, representing an actuatable quality of an actuation target.

The following use case depicts how to define related BCI-O actuation concepts (its description and source code is available online in the spec's human-readable version [1]). Its purpose is to use an actuator capable to control a wheelchair based on the input from a BCI/EEG record (obtained directly from the subject's head). In this use case, Alice is driving a wheelchair throughout a human interface composed of three major components: (1) an EEG sensor capable of reading brain signals, (2) a computing system capable to process and analyze (classify) the brain signals collected from the EEG sensor, and (3) an actuator capable to control the wheelchair's movement (such as direction and acceleration) based on the input from the EEG recordings. The actuator is a device that implements the procedure (actuation) to control the wheelchair, which triggers a series of steps aimed to change the wheelchair's state, such as to decelerate its wheels. The input to the actuator are the observed and processed brain signals that issue specific movement commands. For example, the “slow down” command with the parameters (and values) of “direction” (“go forward” -no change in the direction-) and “acceleration” (-10.5 cm/s² -change in the speed-). The modeled concepts involved in this scenario (see Fig.5), excluding those from the observation component (except EEG-Record and EEG-Device), are listed below:

bci:Subject (1 individual = x1): “Alice”. bci:Session (x1): “a situation where the EEG recording and actuation happened”. bci:Activity (x1): “controlling the automated wheelchair”. bci:Context (x1): “at home”. bci:Context.Scene (x1): “specific indoors situation”. bci:EegRecord (x1): “EEG observation that serves as the input of the actuations”. bci:EegDevice (x1): “EEG device that made the EEG recordings”. bci:Command (x1): “slow down”, actuators' input from the EEG record. bci:Actuator (2 individuals = x2): “the devices that perform the actuations”. bci:Actuation (x2): “procedures that change the state of the wheels via actuators”. bci:ImpactedProperty (x2): “the speed of the wheels (their state)”. bci:ActuationEvent (x2): “reduce the speed of wheels”. bci:ActuationResult (x2): “slowing down” (“effect of decelerating the wheels”). bci:ActuationTarget (x2): “two rear wheels”. bci:Context.Object (composite) (x1): “wheelchair”. bci:Context.Method (x1): “deceleration of a wheel”.

BCI-O's Actuation Model provides a mechanism to correlate the observed/analyzed raw data [1], with the contextual components that the subject interacts with, through actuators (IoT devices), identifying how the actuations affect the context. This is useful in BCI context-aware applications to model how subjects use actuators and interact with the environment, for “intelligent” subject-context personalization.

BCI-O's Actuation Model integrates carefully both standard axiomatization models for actuations, developed by W3C/OGC [2] and IoT [3] [5] communities, based on its Context Model. Thus, its structure follows closely the AAE ODP [4], while aligning to SOSA/SSN and SAN (IoT-O) concepts, based on contextual notions. The SOSA-SAN integrated Actuation Model of BCI-O represents a major contribution to the IoT and BCI communities, especially because its structure includes contextual notions that enables its usage in context-aware BCI-IoT integrated applications. Semantically-enabled BCIs will play a key role in the future “Internet of Brains” interoperating completely with IoT [6]. Under this vision, where one could semantically model, interoperate and control real life objects throughout BCIs connected to the Internet, BCI-O's Actuation Model would become a core semantic structure that integrates BCI, IoT, and contextual concepts in real-world scenarios. It is important noting that as part of the BCI-O's Actuation Model development, the author raised the issue to the W3C Spatial Data on the Web Working Group [7], regarding the mapping of SOSA/SSN to AAE ODP, due of their structural resemblance.

Predicate-will_enable.label: will enable
Predicate-will_enable.description: The predicate 'will enable' indicates that the subject has the potential to create or facilitate an opportunity for something (the object) to happen, become possible, or be achieved. It suggests a causal relationship between the subject and the object, implying that the subject's existence, development, or application will lead to the emergence of the described state or capability.

Predicate-as.label: as
Predicate-as.description: The predicate 'as' indicates a classification or categorization relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject (BCI, for example) can be considered as or equivalent to the object (mainstream human-computer interaction), implying a similarity or analogy between them.

Predicate-throughout.label: throughout
Predicate-throughout.description: The predicate 'throughout' indicates a spatial or temporal scope within which something occurs. It suggests that an action, process, or state extends over the entire duration of its specified range, encompassing all parts or moments simultaneously.

Predicate-integrate.label: integrate
Predicate-integrate.description: To combine or unify disparate elements into a cohesive whole, often resulting in a new entity with enhanced functionality or understanding.

Predicate-defines.label: defines
Predicate-defines.description: The predicate 'defines' indicates a relationship where the subject provides a clear and explicit meaning or scope for the object. It implies that the subject serves as a source, authority, or framework that establishes the boundaries, rules, or principles governing the object's nature, purpose, or functionality.

Predicate-formalizes_and_integrates.label: formalizes and integrates
Predicate-formalizes_and_integrates.description: Formalizes and integrates refers to a process of standardizing and combining concepts, frameworks, or models into a unified structure. This predicate indicates that the subject (a conceptual framework, ontology, or system) defines and unifies disparate elements, such as theories, definitions, or representations, into a coherent whole.

Predicate-includes.label: includes
Predicate-includes.description: The predicate 'includes' indicates that the subject contains or encompasses the object as part of its scope, structure, or definition. It suggests a relationship where the subject has something within it that can be considered an integral component, extension, or aspect.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates a relationship where the subject provides or offers something to someone else. This can be an idea, concept, principle, model, or any other type of information that is being shared with others.

Predicate-determine.label: determine
Predicate-determine.description: To determine means to establish or identify something through measurement, analysis, or observation. It implies a process of discovery or inference that connects the subject (e.g., Brain-Computer Interfaces) with its object (e.g., a user's brain states), revealing some aspect of reality or truth.

Predicate-drive_her_wheelchair_autonomou.label: drive her wheelchair autonomously
Predicate-drive_her_wheelchair_autonomou.description: The predicate 'drive her wheelchair autonomously' describes an action of controlling or operating a device (in this case, a wheelchair), where autonomy implies independence and self-regulation. The subject (Brain-Computer Interfaces  (BCI)) enables or facilitates this autonomous control over the object (wheelchair).

Predicate-will_largely_enable.label: will largely enable
Predicate-will_largely_enable.description: The predicate 'will largely enable' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the actions or events described by the subject will have a significant impact on the ability to perform or achieve something represented by the object. In general, this predicate implies that the subject's influence or contribution will significantly facilitate or empower the object in some way.

Predicate-be_regarded_as.label: be regarded as
Predicate-be_regarded_as.description: The predicate 'be regarded as' indicates a subjective evaluation or assessment of the subject by others. It implies that the object represents an interpretation, classification, or characterization of the subject in some way.

Predicate-fully_interoperating_with.label: fully interoperating with
Predicate-fully_interoperating_with.description: The predicate 'fully interoperating with' indicates a state of seamless communication and coordination between two entities (subject and object), where each entity can exchange information, share resources, or perform tasks together without any hindrances or limitations. This relationship implies that both parties are able to understand, process, and respond to each other's inputs in a unified manner.

Predicate-will_be_a_core_pre-requisite_f.label: will be a core pre-requisite for
Predicate-will_be_a_core_pre-requisite_f.description: Indicates that the subject is an essential condition or requirement necessary to achieve or enable the object. The predicate highlights a fundamental relationship between the subject and object, emphasizing that the former must be present or fulfilled for the latter to exist, function, or operate effectively.

Predicate-require.label: require
Predicate-require.description: The predicate 'require' indicates that a subject has an inherent or necessary need for something to function properly. It implies a sense of necessity or obligation, suggesting that the object is essential or crucial in some way.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' indicates a relationship of equivalence or identity between two entities. It connects the subject and object by stating that they share a common characteristic, property, or nature.

Predicate-integrates.label: integrates
Predicate-integrates.description: The predicate 'integrates' indicates a relationship where the subject (a conceptual framework or system) brings together disparate components, concepts, or models to form a unified whole. This integration can be seen as a process of combining and harmonizing distinct elements into a coherent structure that provides a more comprehensive understanding or functionality.

Predicate-is_properly_aligned_with.label: is properly aligned with
Predicate-is_properly_aligned_with.description: Indicates that two or more ontologies, vocabularies, or conceptual frameworks share a common semantic structure, allowing for seamless integration and mapping between them. This predicate suggests a harmonious relationship where the subject's concepts are compatible with those of the object, enabling efficient data exchange, query processing, and knowledge sharing.

Predicate-is_aligned_with.label: is aligned with
Predicate-is_aligned_with.description: Indicates that two ontologies or conceptual frameworks share a common structure, terminology, or semantics, allowing for integration and mapping between their respective concepts, entities, and relationships.

Predicate-are_connected_to.label: are connected to
Predicate-are_connected_to.description: The predicate 'are connected to' indicates a relationship of association or linking between two entities. It suggests that there exists some kind of logical or physical bond, pathway, or channel that enables communication, interaction, or exchange between the subject and object.

Predicate-makes_an_important_contributio.label: makes an important contribution to
Predicate-makes_an_important_contributio.description: The predicate 'makes an important contribution to' indicates a relationship between the subject (BCI-O in this case) and the object, where the subject has played a significant role in advancing or developing the concept, idea, or field represented by the object. This connection suggests that the subject's actions, research, or efforts have had a meaningful impact on the understanding, application, or evolution of the object.

Predicate-enables.label: enables
Predicate-enables.description: The predicate 'enables' indicates a relationship where the subject provides the necessary conditions or resources for the object to function, operate, or be effective. In general, it suggests that the subject facilitates or makes possible the occurrence of the object's intended action.

Predicate-is_explained_in_a_subsequent_s.label: is explained in a subsequent section for
Predicate-is_explained_in_a_subsequent_s.description: This predicate indicates that the subject provides context or background information necessary to understand the object. The object is likely an explanation, description, or analysis of a concept, process, or phenomenon, and the subject serves as a precursor or foundation for understanding the object.

Predicate-is_summarized_as.label: is summarized as
Predicate-is_summarized_as.description: The predicate 'is summarized as' indicates a relationship where the subject (a concept or idea) has its essence, key points, or main ideas condensed into the object (typically a concise representation). The connection between the subject and object is one of abstraction, highlighting the most important aspects of the original concept.

Predicate-are.label: are
Predicate-are.description: The predicate 'are' indicates a relationship of equivalence or similarity between the subject and object. It suggests that both entities share common characteristics, properties, or attributes, implying a sense of unity or coherence.

Predicate-describes.label: describes
Predicate-describes.description: The predicate 'describes' connects a subject (typically an entity or concept) to its corresponding description or definition. It indicates that the subject's characteristics, features, or essence are being conveyed through the object.

Predicate-depicts.label: depicts
Predicate-depicts.description: The predicate 'depicts' indicates a representation or illustration relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject is being used to convey meaning or information about the object. In this sense, the subject serves as an explanatory tool for understanding the object.

Predicate-uses.label: uses
Predicate-uses.description: The predicate 'uses' indicates a relationship where the subject exploits or employs the object for some purpose. The connection between the subject and object suggests that the subject derives value, benefit, or utility from using the object.

Predicate-is_based_on_the.label: is based on the
Predicate-is_based_on_the.description: The predicate 'is based on the' indicates a relationship where the subject relies on or has its foundation in the object. It suggests that the subject's existence, validity, or meaning is grounded in or derived from the information provided by the object.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: The predicate 'has' indicates a relationship of possession or association between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has control, ownership, or responsibility over the object's attributes, properties, or components.

Predicate-interacts_with.label: interacts with
Predicate-interacts_with.description: The predicate 'interacts with' indicates that there exists some kind of relationship or connection between the subject and object. This relationship can be characterized by mutual influence, exchange, communication, coordination, or any other form of reciprocal action.

Predicate-groups.label: groups
Predicate-groups.description: The predicate 'groups' connects a subject to an object by indicating that the subject consists of or contains multiple entities, which are collectively referred to as groups. This relationship implies a categorization or classification of the subject's components into distinct subsets.

Predicate-and.label: and
Predicate-and.description: The predicate 'and' connects two concepts or entities by indicating a logical conjunction or combination. It implies that the subject and object are related through an additive, inclusive relationship, where both elements contribute to a unified whole.

Predicate-enable.label: enable
Predicate-enable.description: To enable means to make something possible or feasible by providing the necessary conditions, resources, or support. It implies a facilitative relationship between the subject and object, where the subject's presence or action allows for the realization of the object's potential or functionality.

Predicate-defined_for.label: defined for
Predicate-defined_for.description: The predicate 'defined for' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, concepts) has its meaning or scope determined by the object (modeling observations). In general, it suggests that the subject's definition or applicability is tied to or dependent on the characteristics of the object.

Predicate-aligned_to.label: aligned to
Predicate-aligned_to.description: The predicate 'aligned to' indicates a relationship between two entities where one entity (the subject) has its meaning or structure intentionally connected, correlated, or matched with another entity (the object). This connection implies a shared understanding, similarity, or correspondence between the subject and object.

Predicate-related_to.label: related to
Predicate-related_to.description: The predicate 'related to' indicates a connection or association between two entities. It suggests that there exists some kind of relationship, similarity, or relevance between the subject and object.

Predicate-was_developed_based_on.label: was developed based on
Predicate-was_developed_based_on.description: Indicates that a concept or idea (subject) has its foundation, inspiration, or underlying principles in another entity (object), which serves as the basis for its development. This predicate highlights the relationship between the subject and object, emphasizing the role of the latter in shaping the former's characteristics, features, or properties.

Predicate-integrate_and_reconcile.label: integrate and reconcile
Predicate-integrate_and_reconcile.description: To combine or merge two or more entities (subject) into a unified whole by identifying and resolving inconsistencies, contradictions, or discrepancies between them, resulting in a coherent and harmonious relationship with the object.

Predicate-modeling.label: modeling
Predicate-modeling.description: The predicate 'modeling' represents a process of creating or representing an abstract representation (a model) that captures essential characteristics or behaviors of its object, which can be physical systems, processes, or phenomena. This abstraction enables analysis, simulation, prediction, and understanding of the modeled system's dynamics, properties, or responses to various inputs or scenarios.

Predicate-follows_closely.label: follows closely
Predicate-follows_closely.description: The predicate 'follows closely' indicates a relationship of similarity or correspondence between the subject and object, suggesting that they share common characteristics, principles, or patterns. This connection implies a high degree of alignment, coherence, or consistency between the two entities.

Predicate-is_a_part_of.label: is a part of
Predicate-is_a_part_of.description: The predicate 'is a part of' indicates that the subject is an integral component or constituent within the object. It suggests a relationship where the subject is contained, included, or forms a subset within the larger structure defined by the object.

Predicate-follows_closely_the_proposed_A.label: follows closely the proposed Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) ontology design pattern [4]
Predicate-follows_closely_the_proposed_A.description: This predicate indicates that the subject closely adheres to or conforms with a specific ontology design pattern, specifically the Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) pattern. It suggests a strong alignment between the subject's structure and the principles outlined in this design pattern.

Predicate-Carries_out_a_procedure_to_cha.label: Carries out a procedure to change the state of the context using an actuator
Predicate-Carries_out_a_procedure_to_cha.description: This predicate describes the action of implementing a specific process or protocol that alters the current situation or environment by utilizing a device capable of effecting change (actuator). The subject, in this case 'actuations', performs an operation to modify its context using an actuator as a means to achieve the desired outcome.

Predicate-are_defined_at.label: are defined at
Predicate-are_defined_at.description: This predicate indicates that a set of concepts or entities (subject) have their meanings, boundaries, or scope established by reference to a specific point or context (object).

Predicate-is_aligned_to.label: is aligned to
Predicate-is_aligned_to.description: Indicates that two concepts or entities share a common alignment or correspondence. This predicate connects the subject and object by suggesting that they have similar characteristics, properties, or meanings.

Predicate-involves.label: involves
Predicate-involves.description: The predicate 'involves' indicates a relationship of participation or inclusion between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has some level of involvement, connection, or association with the object, which can be understood as being part of, encompassing, or comprising the object.

Predicate-represents_a_transition_someth.label: represents a transition (something that has changed from a state to a different one: actuation target)  ─ a modification (impacted property, as a consequence of an actuation effect)  ─ in the context as the result of an actuation
Predicate-represents_a_transition_someth.description: The predicate represents a transition that has occurred from one state to another, resulting in a modification or change to some property. This connection indicates the causal relationship between an actuation event and its subsequent effect on the subject.

Predicate-represents_an_actuatable_quali.label: represents an actuatable quality (property or characteristic) of an actuation target
Predicate-represents_an_actuatable_quali.description: This predicate indicates that the subject (Impacted Property) has a property or characteristic that can be acted upon or modified by the object (actuation target). The relationship between the subject and object suggests an inherent connection, where the actuation target has the ability to influence or change the state of the impacted property.

Predicate-triggers.label: triggers
Predicate-triggers.description: The predicate 'triggers' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the action or state of being described by the subject leads to or initiates the occurrence of the event or situation represented by the object.

Predicate-changes.label: changes
Predicate-changes.description: The predicate 'changes' indicates a transformation or alteration from one state to another between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has undergone some kind of modification, evolution, or development that affects its relationship with the object.

Predicate-aligned_with.label: aligned with
Predicate-aligned_with.description: Indicates a relationship of correspondence or congruence between two entities, where one entity (the subject) has its characteristics, properties, or behavior matched with those of another entity (the object).

Predicate-impacts.label: impacts
Predicate-impacts.description: The predicate 'impacts' indicates a causal relationship between the subject (an effect or cause) and the object (a property that has been affected). It suggests that the subject's presence, occurrence, or influence leads to changes or consequences on the object.

Predicate-represents.label: represents
Predicate-represents.description: The predicate 'represents' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g. an entity or concept) serves as a symbol, model, or embodiment of the object (e.g. another concept, idea, or phenomenon). In this sense, the subject is seen as a representation or manifestation of the object's essence, characteristics, or properties.

Predicate-is_a.label: is a
Predicate-is_a.description: The predicate 'is a' indicates that the subject has a specific relationship with the object, suggesting that the subject is an instance or member of the category denoted by the object. This connection implies a classification or categorization between the two entities.

Predicate-whose.label: whose
Predicate-whose.description: The predicate 'whose' indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the object possesses or has some characteristic that belongs to the subject. In other words, it specifies an attribute or property of the subject.

Predicate-is_being_manipulated_by.label: is being manipulated by
Predicate-is_being_manipulated_by.description: The predicate 'is being manipulated by' indicates a relationship of control or influence between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject is under the direct or indirect control, guidance, or direction of the object, which may be an agent, entity, or force.

Predicate-is_a_sosaFeatureOfInterest.label: is a sosa:FeatureOfInterest
Predicate-is_a_sosaFeatureOfInterest.description: This predicate indicates that the subject represents an aspect of interest or significance with respect to its relationship with the object. The object is a feature or characteristic that holds importance, relevance, or value for the subject.

Predicate-hasFeatureOfInterest.label: hasFeatureOfInterest
Predicate-hasFeatureOfInterest.description: Indicates that a subject has an interest-bearing feature or characteristic that relates to its essence or nature. This predicate connects the subject with an object representing a property, attribute, or quality that defines or distinguishes it.

Predicate-has_feature_of_interest.label: has feature of interest
Predicate-has_feature_of_interest.description: Indicates that a subject (e.g., an actuation) possesses or exhibits a specific characteristic, attribute, or quality that makes it noteworthy or relevant. This predicate establishes a connection between the subject and object by highlighting a distinctive feature of interest.

Predicate-follows.label: follows
Predicate-follows.description: The predicate 'follows' indicates a relationship of succession or continuity between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject comes after or builds upon the object, often implying a logical or causal connection.

Predicate-is_property_of.label: is property of
Predicate-is_property_of.description: The predicate 'is property of' establishes a relationship between two entities where one entity (the subject) has some inherent or characteristic quality, attribute, or feature that belongs to another entity (the object). This connection indicates that the subject's properties are defined by or attributed to the object.

Predicate-be_opposite_of.label: be opposite of
Predicate-be_opposite_of.description: The predicate 'be opposite of' indicates a relationship between two entities where one entity (the subject) has an opposing or contrasting function, role, or purpose compared to another entity (the object).

Predicate-to.label: to
Predicate-to.description: The predicate 'to' indicates a directional relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the action or entity described by the subject is directed towards or aimed at the object. This can imply control, influence, or transmission of some kind.

Predicate-perform.label: perform
Predicate-perform.description: To perform a predicate indicates the execution or carrying out of an action, task, or process. It implies taking some kind of deliberate and intentional action to bring about a desired outcome or result.

Predicate-represents_a_specific_order_ba.label: represents a specific order (based on a bci:Record) to an actuator to perform an actuation
Predicate-represents_a_specific_order_ba.description: This predicate indicates that the subject (in this case, 'Command') specifies a particular sequence of actions or instructions for the object (the 'Actuator' to perform. The order is based on information contained within a record (bci:Record), which provides context and guidance for the actuation process.

Predicate-represents_a_specific_order_ba.label: represents a specific order based on
Predicate-represents_a_specific_order_ba.description: This predicate indicates that the subject (a command or instruction) has its meaning or significance derived from a specific ordering principle or structure defined by the object, which can be a record, list, sequence, or other structured entity. The connection between the subject and object is one of semantic grounding, where the meaning of the subject is tied to the organization or arrangement specified in the object.

Predicate-executes.label: executes
Predicate-executes.description: The predicate 'executes' indicates the subject's action of carrying out or performing an instruction, plan, or directive specified by the object. It implies a sense of implementation, fulfillment, or realization.

Predicate-connects_to.label: connects to
Predicate-connects_to.description: The predicate 'connects to' indicates a relationship where the subject (an entity or component) has an association with the object (another entity or property), suggesting that there exists some kind of link, attachment, or interaction between them.

Predicate-links_to.label: links to
Predicate-links_to.description: The predicate 'links to' establishes a connection between two concepts or entities, indicating that one (the subject) has some kind of relationship with another (the object). This relationship can be semantic, conceptual, or structural, and may imply similarity, association, categorization, or other forms of logical or meaningful connections.

Predicate-integrates_and_refines_some_mo.label: integrates and refines some modeling considerations of the SOSA and SAN concepts regarding actuations and actuators
Predicate-integrates_and_refines_some_mo.description: This predicate connects a subject (e.g., a model or framework) to an object (e.g., modeling considerations or standards) by describing the process of integrating and refining existing concepts, specifically those related to actuations and actuators. The predicate highlights how the subject incorporates, modifies, and builds upon the ideas presented in SOSA and SAN regarding these topics.

Predicate-regarding.label: regarding
Predicate-regarding.description: The predicate 'regarding' indicates a relationship of relevance or pertinence between the subject (SOSA) and object (actuations and actuators), suggesting that SOSA has some connection, consideration, or focus on actuations and actuators.

Predicate-was_followed_closely_by.label: was followed closely by
Predicate-was_followed_closely_by.description: The predicate 'was followed closely by' indicates a close and persistent connection or association between two entities. It suggests that one entity (the subject) has been accompanied, monitored, or tracked by another entity (the object), often with a high degree of attention or scrutiny.

Predicate-done_with.label: done with
Predicate-done_with.description: Indicates that a process or activity has been completed and terminated its relationship with an object. The subject represents the entity that performed the action of being done with, while the object refers to the thing or concept that was involved in this termination.

Predicate-induces.label: induces
Predicate-induces.description: Induces connects the subject to a consequence or outcome that results from its action. It implies causality between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject's presence, influence, or activity leads to the occurrence of the object.

Predicate-triggered_by.label: triggered by
Predicate-triggered_by.description: The predicate 'triggered by' indicates a causal relationship between an event and its underlying cause or stimulus. It suggests that the subject (event) was initiated, caused, or influenced by the object (Actuator), which served as the catalyst for the occurrence of the event.

Predicate-seeing_as.label: seeing as
Predicate-seeing_as.description: The predicate 'seeing as' indicates a relationship where the subject is perceived or understood to be equivalent to or characterized by the object. It suggests that there is an underlying connection, similarity, or analogy between the two entities.

Predicate-triggered_by_an_actuator.label: triggered by an actuator
Predicate-triggered_by_an_actuator.description: The predicate 'triggered by an actuator' indicates a causal relationship between the subject (a context or event) and the object (an actuator), suggesting that the occurrence of the subject was caused, initiated, or activated by the action of the actuator.

Predicate-changes_the_state_of.label: changes the state of
Predicate-changes_the_state_of.description: The predicate 'changes the state of' indicates a causal relationship between the subject (an entity that initiates or triggers an action) and the object (a property, attribute, or characteristic that undergoes modification). The subject's action or event causes a change in the state of the object, resulting in a new condition or status.

Predicate-comes_from.label: comes from
Predicate-comes_from.description: Indicates a causal or originative relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject has its source, foundation, or inspiration in the object.

Predicate-aligns_to.label: aligns to
Predicate-aligns_to.description: The predicate 'aligns to' indicates a correspondence or similarity between two entities (subject and object), suggesting that they share common characteristics, patterns, or structures. This connection implies a level of coherence, consistency, or equivalence between the subject and object.

Predicate-evaluating_the_scope_and_const.label: evaluating the scope and constraints for each concept, which led to properly define class hierarchies and disjoint axioms
Predicate-evaluating_the_scope_and_const.description: This predicate describes the process of analyzing and understanding the boundaries and limitations (scope and constraints) for each concept or idea. This analysis leads to a clear definition of relationships between concepts, represented by class hierarchies, as well as identifying areas where these concepts do not overlap, captured through disjoint axioms.

Predicate-Aims_to_integrate_and_reconcil.label: Aims to integrate and reconcile SOSA and SAN axioms for modeling actuations and actuators
Predicate-Aims_to_integrate_and_reconcil.description: The predicate aims to establish a harmonious relationship between two formal frameworks (SOSA and SAN), specifically with regards to modeling actuations and actuators. It indicates an intention to merge or align the underlying axioms of these frameworks, potentially creating a unified foundation for representing and analyzing related concepts.

Predicate-depicts_how_to_define_related.label: depicts how to define related
Predicate-depicts_how_to_define_related.description: This predicate indicates that the subject provides a representation or illustration of the process by which two or more entities are connected or associated. The object represents the resulting relationship, concept, or framework that defines how these related entities interact with each other.

Predicate-define_related_actuation_conce.label: define related actuation concepts
Predicate-define_related_actuation_conce.description: This predicate connects a subject (e.g., a system or framework) to an object that describes how it relates to other actuation concepts. It provides insight into the underlying principles, mechanisms, or strategies used by the subject to interact with its environment or control external systems.

Predicate-use.label: use
Predicate-use.description: The predicate 'use' indicates that the subject has a specific function or intention related to the object. It suggests an intentional relationship between the subject and the object, implying that the subject's purpose or goal involves the use of the object.

Predicate-reading.label: reading
Predicate-reading.description: The predicate 'reading' indicates that the subject has access to or interprets information from the object. It implies a process of extracting meaning or understanding from the object, which can be sensory data, written text, or other forms of communication.

Predicate-processing.label: processing
Predicate-processing.description: The predicate 'processing' indicates that the subject performs some kind of operation or transformation on the object. This can include analyzing, interpreting, manipulating, or otherwise handling the object in a way that produces new information, insights, or understanding.

Predicate-controlling.label: controlling
Predicate-controlling.description: The predicate 'controlling' indicates a relationship where the subject has authority or influence over the object's behavior, state, or trajectory. It implies that the subject is responsible for directing, managing, or governing the object in some way.

Predicate-drives_a_wheelchair_throughout.label: drives a wheelchair throughout a human interface composed of three major components
Predicate-drives_a_wheelchair_throughout.description: The predicate 'drives a wheelchair throughout a human interface composed of three major components' describes an action where the subject navigates and interacts with a specific type of user interface, characterized by its composition of three primary elements. The connection between the subject and object lies in the idea that the subject is actively engaging with this interface to achieve some goal or accomplish a task.

Predicate-processes.label: processes
Predicate-processes.description: The predicate 'processes' indicates that the subject performs some kind of operation or transformation on the object. This can include actions such as analyzing, interpreting, manipulating, or transforming the object in some way.

Predicate-implements.label: implements
Predicate-implements.description: The predicate 'implements' indicates a relationship where the subject (an entity or system) carries out, enacts, or puts into practice the object (a plan, method, procedure, etc.), thereby actualizing its intended purpose.

Predicate-issue.label: issue
Predicate-issue.description: To issue means to produce or generate a particular outcome, instruction, or command as a result of processing or analyzing information. In this sense, it connects the subject (the source of analysis) with the object (the resulting action or decision), indicating that the subject's input has led to the creation of something new.

Predicate-excluding_those_from.label: excluding those from
Predicate-excluding_those_from.description: The predicate 'excluding those from' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, modeled concepts) excludes or omits certain entities that originate from or are associated with the object (the observation component). This connection highlights the distinction between what is being considered and what is not relevant to the consideration.

Predicate-via.label: via
Predicate-via.description: The predicate 'via' indicates a means or method by which an action or process occurs. It connects the subject (the procedures that change the state of the wheels) to the object (Actuator), suggesting that the actuators are the instruments or tools used to achieve this outcome.

Predicate-commands.label: commands
Predicate-commands.description: The predicate 'commands' indicates that the subject (an entity or action) exercises control over the object (a process, behavior, or outcome), implying direction, instruction, or regulation.

Predicate-developed_by.label: developed by
Predicate-developed_by.description: The predicate 'developed by' indicates that a subject (typically an organization or individual) has taken responsibility and contributed to the creation, design, or evolution of something (the object), which can be a concept, model, standard, methodology, etc. The relationship suggests a causal link between the subject's actions and the resulting product or idea.

Predicate-aligning_to.label: aligning to
Predicate-aligning_to.description: The predicate 'aligning to' indicates a relationship where the subject's structure or organization is matched, correlated, or mapped to the object's conceptual framework. This connection implies that there exists a correspondence between the two entities, allowing for the comparison and integration of their respective structures.

Predicate-follows_closely_the_structure_.label: follows closely the structure of
Predicate-follows_closely_the_structure_.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has a similar organizational or structural pattern to the object. It suggests a close correspondence between the internal structure of the subject and the object, implying a high degree of similarity in terms of organization, categorization, or conceptual framework.

Predicate-raised_the_issue_to.label: raised the issue to
Predicate-raised_the_issue_to.description: To raise an issue to someone or something means to bring a problem or concern to their attention. This predicate indicates that the subject has taken action to notify, alert, or inform the object about a particular matter.

Predicate-represents_a_major_contributio.label: represents a major contribution to
Predicate-represents_a_major_contributio.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has made a significant advancement or innovation that significantly impacts or influences the object. The connection between the subject and object suggests a relationship of causality, where the subject's contribution has led to meaningful progress or growth in the field or community represented by the object.

Predicate-is_integrated_into.label: is integrated into
Predicate-is_integrated_into.description: The predicate 'is integrated into' indicates a relationship where the subject (a conceptual or structural entity) is part of, contained within, or composed by the object. This integration implies that the subject loses its independent existence and becomes an integral component of the larger structure defined by the object.

Predicate-will_become.label: will become
Predicate-will_become.description: The predicate 'will become' indicates a transformation or evolution from one state to another. It implies that the subject (the degree as context-based semantic interoperability, in this example) will undergo a change and eventually assume the characteristics described by the object (BCI-O Context Model). The relationship between the subject and object is one of development, maturation, or refinement.

Predicate-aligns.label: aligns
Predicate-aligns.description: The predicate 'aligns' indicates a relationship where the subject establishes or maintains correspondence with its representation or equivalent in the object, often implying similarity, equivalence, or consistency between them.

Predicate-is_described_in.label: is described in
Predicate-is_described_in.description: Indicates that a subject provides information about or explains itself through an object, which can be a written description, documentation, or other form of exposition.

Predicate-describe.label: describe
Predicate-describe.description: To characterize or outline the essential features of something, typically providing a concise and informative representation that captures its key aspects.

Predicate-is_based_on.label: is based on
Predicate-is_based_on.description: Indicates that the subject's foundation or underlying principles are derived from or grounded in the object. The predicate 'is based on' suggests a relationship of dependence, where the subject relies on the object as its basis for existence, validity, or functionality.

Predicate-will_integrate.label: will integrate
Predicate-will_integrate.description: To indicate a future action of combining or unifying two entities (subject and object), resulting in a new whole that incorporates aspects from both. This predicate suggests a process of merging, blending, or assimilating the subject's capabilities with those of the object to create something novel.

Predicate-formalize.label: formalize
Predicate-formalize.description: To formalize means to establish a systematic and rigorous structure or framework for something, typically involving the use of standardized concepts, terminology, and rules. This process connects the subject (e.g., an abstract model) with the object (e.g., an ontology), creating a well-defined and organized representation that can be used as a foundation for further development, analysis, or application.

Predicate-is_a_core_pre-requisite_for.label: is a core pre-requisite for
Predicate-is_a_core_pre-requisite_for.description: The predicate 'is a core pre-requisite for' indicates that the subject has an essential condition or requirement that must be met in order to achieve, utilize, or interact with the object. In other words, it highlights a fundamental necessity or prerequisite that underlies the relationship between the subject and the object.

Predicate-is_described_by.label: is described by
Predicate-is_described_by.description: The predicate 'is described by' indicates a relationship between two entities where one entity (the subject) provides an explanation, summary, or interpretation of the other entity (the object). This connection implies that the subject has been documented, explained, or formalized in some way to facilitate understanding and communication about the object.

Predicate-combine.label: combine
Predicate-combine.description: To combine refers to bringing together or uniting two or more entities (concepts, frameworks, etc.) into a single entity that represents the integration of their respective aspects. This predicate indicates a process of merging, aggregating, or synthesizing distinct elements to form a new whole.

Predicate-formalizes.label: formalizes
Predicate-formalizes.description: Formalizes establishes a systematic and standardized framework for representing or organizing concepts, entities, or relationships. It implies a structured and coherent approach to describing or defining something, often in a way that provides clarity, precision, and consistency.

Predicate-align.label: align
Predicate-align.description: To bring into a state of correspondence or congruence between two entities (subject and object), often implying a process of synchronization, coordination, or matching. This predicate suggests an effort to harmonize or standardize the subject with respect to the object, potentially resulting in improved compatibility, efficiency, or effectiveness.

Predicate-model.label: model
Predicate-model.description: To represent or simulate a conceptual framework that explains and predicts phenomena, behaviors, or patterns. The predicate 'model' establishes an abstract representation of a system, process, or phenomenon, which can be used to understand, analyze, predict, or control its behavior.

Predicate-is_an_ontological_metadata_ove.label: is an ontological metadata overlay for
Predicate-is_an_ontological_metadata_ove.description: This predicate indicates that the subject is a layer of metadata that provides additional information about or context to the object. The relationship suggests that the subject serves as an enrichment mechanism for the object, providing supplementary details that can be used to better understand its meaning, structure, or relationships.

Predicate-is_integrated_by.label: is integrated by
Predicate-is_integrated_by.description: The predicate 'is integrated by' indicates a relationship where one entity (the subject) has its components or aspects unified with another entity (the object), resulting in a cohesive whole. This integration can be seen as a process of combining, merging, or synthesizing the subject's parts to form a new, more comprehensive structure that is characterized by the object.

Predicate-enable_integration.label: enable integration
Predicate-enable_integration.description: To enable integration means to facilitate or make possible the connection and interaction between different entities, systems, or components. This predicate indicates that something (the subject) provides a mechanism or framework for combining or linking other things (the object), often in order to achieve greater functionality, efficiency, or understanding.

Predicate-enable_seamless_communication.label: enable seamless communication
Predicate-enable_seamless_communication.description: To enable seamless communication means to facilitate a smooth and efficient exchange of information or ideas between entities, individuals, or systems. This predicate connects the subject (context- or situation-specific semantic interoperability) with the object (novel interfaces), implying that the novel interfaces are designed to overcome potential barriers or limitations in understanding, thereby enabling effective communication.

Predicate-allow.label: allow
Predicate-allow.description: The predicate 'allow' indicates a permission or authorization for something to occur. It implies that the subject has granted consent or created an environment where the object can exist, operate, or be used.

Predicate-integrate_seamlessly.label: integrate seamlessly
Predicate-integrate_seamlessly.description: To connect or unify two entities (subject and object) in a way that creates a harmonious and efficient whole, without any noticeable gaps or disruptions. This predicate implies a smooth transition from one entity to another, allowing them to function together seamlessly.

Predicate-become.label: become
Predicate-become.description: The predicate 'become' indicates a transformation or evolution from one state to another. It implies that the subject will change its nature, properties, or characteristics in some way, resulting in a new relationship with the object.

Predicate-describe_how.label: describe how
Predicate-describe_how.description: The predicate 'describe how' connects a subject (a conceptual model or framework) to an object (another concept or system), indicating that the subject provides insight into, outlines the process of, or explains the underlying mechanism for achieving something described by the object. In essence, it describes the relationship between the two concepts.

Predicate-design.label: design
Predicate-design.description: To design means to intentionally create or conceptualize a plan, system, process, or product that meets specific requirements, constraints, and goals. The predicate 'design' connects the subject (the entity responsible for designing) with the object (the thing being designed), indicating an intentional act of creation, planning, or problem-solving.

Predicate-formalizes_and_integrates_doma.label: formalizes and integrates domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model
Predicate-formalizes_and_integrates_doma.description: This predicate connects the subject to its object by formalizing and integrating domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model, effectively creating a unified framework that brings together disparate components. The resulting structure enables a deeper understanding of complex systems or domains, facilitating more informed decision-making and improved performance.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject conceptually includes or encompasses the object as a more general category. It represents an hierarchical relationship where the subject is a parent or superordinate to the object, which serves as its child or subordinate.
